awd_titl_txt: The 2023 Online Undergraduate Resource Fair for the Advancement and Alliance of Marginalized Mathematicians
awd_abstract_narration:
This project serves the national interest by providing undergraduate and graduate students in the mathematical sciences with "insider" knowledge that will allow them to make informed decisions about their educational and career choices. Specifically, this project will support the fourth offering of the Online Undergraduate Resource Fair for the Advancement and Alliance of Marginalized Mathematicians, a two-day online conference organized by current students. Building from three prior offerings from 2020 to 2022, the 2023 conference will include six main activities for participating students: (1) Our Stories talks, where recent PhD recipients will share their experiences; (2) crash courses that provide brief overviews of fields of mathematics common in undergraduate research; (3) a summer opportunities panel; (4) a student experiences panel; (5) two plenary presentations; and (6) two virtual networking lunches. Each activity is designed to shine a light on aspects of graduate education and career opportunities that can be complex for participants to explore on their own. 

Too often, students can be excluded from educational and career opportunities simply because they are not "in the know." This may be due to insufficient mentorship, underdeveloped institutional advising systems, or other circumstances. This is a particularly common challenge for individuals from low-income backgrounds, first-generation students, and students from populations that have historically been underrepresented in the mathematical sciences. This conference looks to provide mentoring and networking opportunities to promote access to opportunities for all students. The conference builds upon three pillars: (1) sharing information about resources and opportunities through conference presentations and panel discussions; (2) providing access to role models and representation through a careful selection of speakers with diverse identities and experiences and a history of supporting students; and (3) providing access to networking opportunities. A participant overview will be disseminated and an assessment of the conference's effectiveness will be conducted using data from a Zoom meeting report, a survey immediately after the conference, and a second survey four months after the conference. The NSF IUSE: EDU Program supports research and development projects to improve the effectiveness of STEM education for all students.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The Online Undergraduate Resource Fair for the Alliance and Advancement of Marginalized Mathematicians (OURFA2M2) is a two-day virtual conference aimed at undergraduate mathematics students from marginalized backgrounds. The conference was held virtually on November 18-19. The conference is held virtually in order to be widely accessible. We use the term marginalized backgrounds to include but not limit to students considered to be part of an underrepresented minority group in mathematics, LGBTQ+ students, female students, community college students, and first generation college students. The goals of the conference are to (1) inform students about resources and opportunities that will help them develop their careers, (2) represent and uplift marginalized mathematicians who will be role models for conference participants, and (3) provide access to networking opportunities.

The first day of the conference saw 174 unique zoom participants while the second day saw 110 unique zoom participants. Overall there were 216 unique zoom participants.

631 people registered for the conference, and 90.2% reported that they had not previously attended OURFA2M2. The first day of the conference saw 174 unique zoom participants while the second day saw 110 unique zoom participants. Overall there were 216 unique zoom participants. 

At least 77.7% of registrants were undergraduates, at least 9.4% were professors, and at least 6.3% were graduate students. Undergraduates are the target audience for the conference, so a high percentage of undergraduate registrants is ideal. Faculty, graduate students, and other non-undergraduate registrants are generally a mix of invited conference speakers, mathematical community members attending to support undergraduates, and mathematical community members who feel they have something to learn from the conference despite not being the target audience. OURFA2M2 is open to all participants who feel they would benefit from it and/or want to support our work. 77.5% of all registrants reported that they identified with at least one marginalized identity.

Our goal was to invite qualified, experienced speakers from a range of diverse backgrounds. We used several avenues to identify potential speakers, including: personal knowledge of mathematics professionals; nominations and recommendations from mathematics professionals working to increase the representation and advancement of underrepresented minority students in math; nominations and recommendations from our social media and email list networks; and biographical descriptions of mathematicians. The biographical resources utilized for the speaker selection include Mathematically Gifted and Black, The 500 Queer Scientists Project, The Spectra Outlist, Lathisms, Indigenous Mathematicians, The Math Alliance’s mentor list, Mathematicians of the African Diaspora, and the AMS Living Proof Blog. The conference consisted of seven different session types: Our Stories Talks, Crash Courses, Plenary Talks, Networking Lunches, the Opportunities Panel, the Experiences Panel, and a Resource Presentation.

Among 32 undergraduates who attended the conference and responded to our post-conference feedback survey:

  • 94% said they felt mostly or very welcome at the conference
  • 75% said OURFA2M2 was their first math conference
  • 88% said they felt more prepared to pursue a career in mathematics after the conference 
  • 97% said they would likely or definitely recommend OURFA2M2 to a friend or another student
  • 44% said they previously knew about few, almost none, or none of the career building resources they learned about at OURFA2M2

Overall we were very pleased with the outcomes of this project and plan to continue to offer the conference and additional resources for our target audience. The data collected from the project has proven that the conference is successful and quite beneficial to undergraduate math students and faculty. The feedback that we have received will also help shape future conferences and other offerings.


 

 


Last Modified: 01/09/2025
Modified by: Kiera L Palma
